content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate specified areas within one or more States as high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on specific criteria. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate specified areas within one or more States as high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. Federal assistance will be provided through the establishment of criminal street gang enforcement teams in these designated areas. The Attorney General will establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas to coordinate investigation, disruption, apprehension, and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders in those areas. The Attorney General will establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, coordinating investigation, disruption, apprehension, and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders in the area. Reassignment or detailing of personnel from Federal departments or agencies to each enforcement team will be directed. The Attorney General will establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, coordinating investigation, disruption, apprehension, and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. Federal departments or agencies will provide personnel and funding for the operation of these enforcement teams. The Attorney General will establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, coordinating investigation, disruption, apprehension, and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. Funding will be provided for the operation and meetings of these enforcement teams to ensure effective operation through intelligence sharing and best practices. The Attorney General will establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, consisting of agents and officers from the FBI and DEA, to ensure effective operation through intelligence sharing and best practices. Each criminal street gang enforcement team will include agents and officers from the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals Service, DHS, and HUD. The Attorney General considers various agencies and criteria when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals Service, DHS, HUD, state and local law enforcement, and prosecutors. The Attorney General considers agencies like the FBI, DEA, ATF, US Marshals Service, DHS, HUD, state, and local law enforcement, and prosecutors when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on criteria such as current and predicted gang crime levels and the relationship between violent crime and gang activity. The Attorney General considers current and predicted levels of gang crime activity, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, and the commitment of resources by state and local law enforcement agencies in designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General evaluates gang crime levels, the connection between violent crime and gangs, state and local law enforcement resources, and the potential impact of increased federal resources on addressing gang activities. The Attorney General can hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in high-intensity interstate gang areas. The Attorney General is authorized to hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys for high-intensity interstate gang areas, with necessary appropriations authorized. SEC. 3.
